channelDetails.title: How do you use the internet mindfully?

contents.title: On quitting social media
contents.content_html: "Yes, every time you open your browser, you might be at a loss to decide what to do. You won‚Äôt know where to go next, because your go-to web hangout ‚Äî Facebook ‚Äî is out. But don‚Äôt worry. This won‚Äôt last long. You‚Äôll soon discover distractions of a different kind and even find more time to learn a new hobby. I latched on to interesting newsletters and feeds as a replacement for social media."
contents.description_html:
via
https://www.makeuseof.com/tag/what-happens-when-you-quit-social-media-i-found-out/

metadata.description: [The Creative Independent](https://thecreativeindependent.com/) is a growing resource of emotional and practical guidance for creative people.

contents.title: Mark Dorf on sincerity, balance, and the internet
contents.generated_title: Mark Dorf on sincerity, balance, and the internet
contents.content_html:
"I started making digital works because I had an old laptop, and I could play in there. It didn‚Äôt require space, and I could take it places. That naturally led me to a lot of internet communities. I was also looking for this more conceptual or theoretical kind of conversation... [and] internet culture allowed for a special kind of conversation and exchange."

‚Äî Mark Dorf
contents.description_html: via: https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/mark-dorf-on-sincerity-balance-and-the-internet/
contents.content:
"I started making digital works because I had an old laptop, and I could play in there. It didn‚Äôt require space, and I could take it places. That naturally led me to a lot of internet communities. I was also looking for this more conceptual or theoretical kind of conversation... [and] internet culture allowed for a special kind of conversation and exchange."

contents.title: Year End: On worldbuilding
contents.content_html:
"The internet is an amazing space when it reminds us how vast and diverse the world is. Early dot-com websites reflected this notion of an ‚Äúexpanding space‚Äù in their company names, using words like ‚Äúearth,‚Äù ‚Äúglobe,‚Äù ‚Äúworld,‚Äù ‚Äúspace,‚Äù or ‚Äúsystem‚Äù to describe their growing networks."

‚Äî Elliott Radner
contents.description_html: via: https://thecreativeindependent.com/approaches/year-end-on-world-building/
contents.content:
"The internet is an amazing space when it reminds us how vast and diverse the world is. Early dot-com websites reflected this notion of an ‚Äúexpanding space‚Äù in their company names, using words like ‚Äúearth,‚Äù ‚Äúglobe,‚Äù ‚Äúworld,‚Äù ‚Äúspace,‚Äù or ‚Äúsystem‚Äù to describe their growing networks."

‚Äî [Elliott Radner](https://thecreativeindependent.com/approaches/year-end-on-world-building/)

contents.title: "How I got my attention back" by Craig Mod
contents.generated_title: "How I got my attention back" by Craig Mod
contents.content_html: "It‚Äôs important to emphasize that for certain members of certain groups, online is non-negotiable. Total disconnection is not only unsustainable for most people, but can also be an unnecessary act of self-sabotage. Wherever you fall on the spectrum of leveraging the network for social good, having control over your attention can only make your efforts stronger. I refuse to believe otherwise. Take the morning. Hell, just take the first hour of the morning. Make a plan. Own your attention. A lack of ownership of attention can only make you a weaker leader."
contents.description_html:
Excerpt from "How I got my attention back" by Craig Mod

Published in Wired on 1/13/17

https://www.wired.com/2017/01/how-i-got-my-attention-back/#.ciowkpe2q
contents.content: "It‚Äôs important to emphasize that for certain members of certain groups, online is non-negotiable. Hell, just take the first hour of the morning. Make a plan. Own your attention. A lack of ownership of attention can only make you a weaker leader."

metadata.description: [The Creative Independent](https://thecreativeindependent.com/) is a growing resource of emotional and practical guidance for creative people.

contents.title: Go Deeper
contents.content_html:
You have to be curious about the world in which you live. Look things up. Chase down every reference. Go deeper than anybody else - that's how you'll get ahead. (p. 19)

Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.
contents.description_html: Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.
contents.content:
You have to be curious about the world in which you live. Look things up. Chase down every reference. Go deeper than anybody else - that's how you'll get ahead. (p. 19)

Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.
contents.description: Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.

metadata.description:
Csaba Osvath is a doctoral candidate at the University of South Florida, pursuing literacy studies with a special focus on qualitative methods and arts based research. His research explores the epistemological and pedagogical roles/functions of artmaking in the context of literacy education. His current project is the creation of a mixed media collage technique and a methodological artistic process for knowledge acquisition and knowledge production in educational settings. Csaba grew up and studied theology and horticulture in Hungary, prior to his graduate studies and service as an artist and educator in the United States. 

https://csabaosvath.wordpress.com/

contents.title: The Slow Media Manifesto
contents.description_html: (see original Manifesto in German) The first decade of the 21st century, the so-called 'naughties', has brought profound changes to the technological foundations of the media landscape. The key buzzwords are networks, the Internet and social media. In the second decade, people will not search for new technologies allowing for even easier, faster and low-priced content production.
contents.description: (see original Manifesto in German) The first decade of the 21st century, the so-called 'naughties', has brought profound changes to the technological foundations of the media landscape. The key buzzwords are networks, the Internet and social media. In the second decade, people will not search for new technologies allowing for even easier, faster and low-priced content production.

contents.title: Personal Computer, Vending Machine
contents.description_html: In the last month or so, at least eight people have asked me why I arrange my device the way I do. I'll take some time to describe my phone and how I use it, and why I think my personal arrangement is a good idea in general.
contents.description: In the last month or so, at least eight people have asked me why I arrange my device the way I do. I'll take some time to describe my phone and how I use it, and why I think my personal arrangement is a good idea in general.

contents.title: Borges, The Universe And The Infinite Library
contents.generated_title: Borges, The Universe And The Infinite Library
contents.description_html: In the short story The Library of Babel , the great Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges constructs a metaphorical replica of the universe, both celebrating and teasing the cosmologists of his time. His irony is timeless and has much to say about current efforts as well.
contents.description: In the short story The Library of Babel , the great Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges constructs a metaphorical replica of the universe, both celebrating and teasing the cosmologists of his time. His irony is timeless and has much to say about current efforts as well.

source.title: Borges, The Universe And The Infinite Library

contents.title: how to do nothing - Jenny Odell - Medium
contents.generated_title: how to do nothing - Jenny Odell - Medium
contents.description_html: I'd like to start off by saying that this talk is grounded in a particular location, and that is the Morcom Amphitheatre of Roses in Oakland, California, otherwise known simply as "the rose garden." In the most basic sense, that's because I largely wrote this talk in the rose garden.

metadata.description: [The Creative Independent](https://thecreativeindependent.com/) is a growing resource of emotional and practical guidance for creative people.

contents.title: Peter Burr on engaging honestly with the world
contents.generated_title: Peter Burr on engaging honestly with the world
contents.content_html:
"As I was studying art in my late teens, early 20s, I discovered the power of the internet and digital tools for translating image-making into something more, and it just exploded from there. When I was studying art practice, the computer became exciting as a new tool for sculptural practices. It became this interesting way to explore how to approach something that is known or legible and blow it out."

‚Äî Peter Burr
contents.description_html: via: https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/peter-burr-on-engaging-honestly-with-the-world/
contents.content:
"As I was studying art in my late teens, early 20s, I discovered the power of the internet and digital tools for translating image-making into something more, and it just exploded from there. When I was studying art practice, the computer became exciting as a new tool for sculptural practices. It became this interesting way to explore how to approach something that is known or legible and blow it out."

‚Äî [Peter Burr](https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/peter-burr-on-engaging-honestly-with-the-world/)

contents.title: The Case for Digital Wellness - Clickbait Magazine
contents.generated_title: The Case for Digital Wellness - Clickbait Magazine
contents.description_html: Life in 2017: Navigating the Era of Peak Dopamine Addiction Yup. We're very much addicted to tech‚Ää-‚Ääand addiction comes with its own set of stigmas. Dependence, disfunction, dysmorphia. Death. But what what if our dependence on technology actually had the opposite effect and our dopamine addiction was a force for good, not evil?
contents.description: Life in 2017: Navigating the Era of Peak Dopamine Addiction Yup. We're very much addicted to tech‚Ää-‚Ääand addiction comes with its own set of stigmas. Dependence, disfunction, dysmorphia. Death. But what what if our dependence on technology actually had the opposite effect and our dopamine addiction was a force for good, not evil?

source.title: The Case for Digital Wellness - Clickbait Magazine

[@msutherl](https://twitter.com/msutherl)

contents.title: How To Reclaim Your Newsfeed - The Mission - Medium
contents.generated_title: How To Reclaim Your Newsfeed - The Mission - Medium
contents.description_html: Social media newsfeeds have hijacked your attention. It's time to reclaim it. L ast week during another sad desk lunch, I found myself mindlessly scrolling through my Facebook feed and suddenly feeling boxed-in by the same content I've seen over and over again.
contents.description: Social media newsfeeds have hijacked your attention. It's time to reclaim it. L ast week during another sad desk lunch, I found myself mindlessly scrolling through my Facebook feed and suddenly feeling boxed-in by the same content I've seen over and over again.

source.title: How To Reclaim Your Newsfeed - The Mission - Medium

contents.title: HAWRAF on being transparent about your process
contents.generated_title: HAWRAF on being transparent about your process
contents.content_html:
"The internet‚Äôs become a great platform for that. The ability, for us, to give ourselves the tools to make the things we want to make and using the internet as a platform to disperse them as widely as possible. There are so many things you can learn online now. You can use it to highlight the stuff that you‚Äôre doing, make the things you want to make, make money if you need to make money‚Ä¶"

‚Äî Carly Ayres of HAWRAF
contents.description_html: via: https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/hawraf-on-being-transparent-about-your-process/
contents.content:
"The internet‚Äôs become a great platform for that. The ability, for us, to give ourselves the tools to make the things we want to make and using the internet as a platform to disperse them as widely as possible. There are so many things you can learn online now. You can use it to highlight the stuff that you‚Äôre doing, make the things you want to make, make money if you need to make money‚Ä¶"

contents.title: The Internet
contents.content_html:
The Internet can be more than just a resting place to publish your finished ideas - it can also be an incubator for ideas that aren't fully formed, a birthing center for developing work that you haven't started yet. (p. 82)

Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.
contents.description_html: Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.
contents.content:

wholesome, weird, dreamy

contents.content_html:
I was made for the library, not the classroom. The classroom was a jail of other people‚Äôs interests. The library was open, unending, free.

‚ÄîTa-Nehisi Coates (Between the World and Me)
contents.content:

contents.title: Weiser M and Seely Brown J (Xerox PARC), Designing Calm Technology (1995)
contents.generated_title: Weiser M and Seely Brown J (Xerox PARC), Designing Calm Technology (1995)
contents.description_html: Mark Weiser and John Seely Brown Xerox PARC December 21, 1995 Bits flowing through the wires of a computer network are ordinarily invisible. But a radically new tool shows those bits through motion, sound, and even touch. It communicates both light and heavy network traffic.
contents.description: Mark Weiser and John Seely Brown Xerox PARC December 21, 1995 Bits flowing through the wires of a computer network are ordinarily invisible. But a radically new tool shows those bits through motion, sound, and even touch. It communicates both light and heavy network traffic.

contents.title: Center for Humane Technology
contents.description_html: The Center for Humane Technology is a world-class team of former tech insiders and CEOs who are advancing thoughtful solutions to change the culture, business incentives, design techniques, and organizational structures driving how technology hijacks our brains.
contents.description: The Center for Humane Technology is a world-class team of former tech insiders and CEOs who are advancing thoughtful solutions to change the culture, business incentives, design techniques, and organizational structures driving how technology hijacks our brains.

metadata.description:
Csaba Osvath is a doctoral candidate at the University of South Florida, pursuing literacy studies with a special focus on qualitative methods and arts based research. His research explores the epistemological and pedagogical roles/functions of artmaking in the context of literacy education. His current project is the creation of a mixed media collage technique and a methodological artistic process for knowledge acquisition and knowledge production in educational settings. Csaba grew up and studied theology and horticulture in Hungary, prior to his graduate studies and service as an artist and educator in the United States. 

https://csabaosvath.wordpress.com/

contents.title: Borges, The Universe And The Infinite Library
contents.generated_title: Borges, The Universe And The Infinite Library
contents.description_html: In the short story The Library of Babel , the great Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges constructs a metaphorical replica of the universe, both celebrating and teasing the cosmologists of his time. His irony is timeless and has much to say about current efforts as well.
contents.description: In the short story The Library of Babel , the great Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges constructs a metaphorical replica of the universe, both celebrating and teasing the cosmologists of his time. His irony is timeless and has much to say about current efforts as well.

In the most basic sense, that's because I largely wrote this talk in the rose garden.

contents.title: Peter Burr on engaging honestly with the world
contents.generated_title: Peter Burr on engaging honestly with the world
contents.content_html:
"As I was studying art in my late teens, early 20s, I discovered the power of the internet and digital tools for translating image-making into something more, and it just exploded from there. When I was studying art practice, the computer became exciting as a new tool for sculptural practices. It became this interesting way to explore how to approach something that is known or legible and blow it out."

‚Äî Peter Burr
contents.description_html: via: https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/peter-burr-on-engaging-honestly-with-the-world/
contents.content:

contents.generated_title: The Case for Digital Wellness - Clickbait Magazine
contents.description_html: Life in 2017: Navigating the Era of Peak Dopamine Addiction Yup. We're very much addicted to tech‚Ää-‚Ääand addiction comes with its own set of stigmas. Dependence, disfunction, dysmorphia. Death. But what what if our dependence on technology actually had the opposite effect and our dopamine addiction was a force for good, not evil?

contents.generated_title: HAWRAF on being transparent about your process
contents.content_html:
"The internet‚Äôs become a great platform for that. The ability, for us, to give ourselves the tools to make the things we want to make and using the internet as a platform to disperse them as widely as possible. There are so many things you can learn online now. You can use it to highlight the stuff that you‚Äôre doing, make the things you want to make, make money if you need to make money‚Ä¶"

‚Äî Carly Ayres of HAWRAF

contents.title: The Internet
contents.content_html:
The Internet can be more than just a resting place to publish your finished ideas - it can also be an incubator for ideas that aren't fully formed, a birthing center for developing work that you haven't started yet. (p. 82)

Kleon, A. (2012). Steal Like An Artist. Ten Things Nobody Told You About Being Creative. Workman Publishing Company: New York.

contents.title: Mindfulness: Knowing The Present
contents.content_html:
Mindfulness entails knowing what is happening in the present moment while it is happening. It is a training in how not to be lost in thoughts, opinions, and reactivity. It is also a training in how to see things as they really are, as opposed to seeing them through the often distorted lens of preconceived ideas and interpretations.

Fronsdal, Gil (2001). Issue at Hand (Kindle Locations 132-134). self. Kindle Edition.
contents.description_html: Fronsdal, Gil (2001-12-01). Issue at Hand (Kindle Locations 132-134). self. Kindle Edition.

contents.title: Stop using Facebook and start using your browser
contents.generated_title: Stop using Facebook and start using your browser
contents.content_html:
Literally, all you need to do: Type in web addresses. Use autofill! Or even: Google the website you want to go to, and go to it. Then bookmark it. Then go back every now and again.

Instead of reading stories that get to you because they‚Äôre popular, or just happen to be in your feed at that moment, you‚Äôll read stories that get to you because you chose to go to them. Sounds simple, and insignificant, and almost too easy, right?

It‚Äôs only easy, and simple to do. As for why you should do it: It‚Äôs definitely not simple, nor insignificant. By choosing to be a reader of websites whose voices and ideas you‚Äôre fundamentally interested in and care about, you‚Äôre taking control.

And by doing that, you‚Äôll chip away at the incentive publishers have to create headlines and stories weaponized for the purpose of sharing on social media. You‚Äôll be stripping away at the motivation for websites everywhere (including this one) to make dumb hollow mindgarbage. At the same time, you‚Äôll increase the incentive for these websites to be (if nothing else) more consistent and less desperate for your attention.
contents.content:
Literally, all you need to do: Type in web addresses. Use autofill! Or even: Google the website you want to go to, and go to it. Then bookmark it. Then go back every now and again.

Instead of reading stories that get to you because they‚Äôre popular, or just happen to be in your feed at that moment, you‚Äôll read stories that get to you because you chose to go to them. Sounds simple, and insignificant, and almost too easy, right?

It‚Äôs only easy, and simple to do. As for why you should do it: It‚Äôs definitely not simple, nor insignificant. By choosing to be a reader of websites whose voices and ideas you‚Äôre fundamentally interested in and care about, you‚Äôre taking control.

And by doing that, you‚Äôll chip away at the incentive publishers have to create headlines and stories weaponized for the purpose of sharing on social media. You‚Äôll be stripping away at the motivation for websites everywhere (including this one) to make dumb hollow mindgarbage. At the same time, you‚Äôll increase the incentive for these websites to be (if nothing else) more consistent and less desperate for your attention.

source.title: Stop using Facebook and start using your browser

contents.title: Vito Acconci
contents.content_html: I love systems, but systems can act, they can determine too much. You have to find a way to misuse a system. Not even necessarily purposefully, you have to realize suddenly that you‚Äôre misusing it and now you‚Äôve expanded it, you‚Äôve let the system spill and it hasn‚Äôt become a trap.

contents.title: Principles for Slower Internet
contents.content_html: "A Slower Internet... requires that dissimilar tasks occur in a diversity of spaces on a multitude of devices. Living with information does not mean that we have to give any type of machine a monopoly over our attention. Slower Internet is a process of cultivating a garden of machines that fit localized, individual desires."
contents.description_html:
Excerpt from "Principles for Slower Internet" by the Consortium for Slower Internet

via:
http://slowerinternet.com/principles.html

contents.title: Ben Kinmont, Forse, Perhaps (1995)
contents.content_html: Perhaps. Slow down. In so far as we care for one another, you are my vision and I am for you. We have come to this place on our way to something else, on our way to by groceries, to see more art, or to visit a friend for a cup of coffee. These pathways sometimes cross, as ours have today, and create the opportunity for bridging a gap that separates the self from the other. From one idea or moment to another. I am asking you to help me bridge the gap which separates the art world from the non-art world. In so doing, perhaps we can create a situation of trust and generosity between myself and you. Perhaps I can help you with a household chore to share in your daily responsibilities. Perhaps, in exchange, we could discuss my concerns about the art-life dynamic and you could help me to make a sculpture.
contents.description_html: Source: http://www.benkinmont.com/projects/forsect.htm
contents.content: **Perhaps.** Slow down. In so far as we care for one another, you are my vision and I am for you. We have come to this place on our way to something else, on our way to by groceries, to see more art, or to visit a friend for a cup of coffee. These pathways sometimes cross, as ours have today, and create the opportunity for bridging a gap that separates the self from the other. From one idea or moment to another. I am asking you to help me bridge the gap which separates the art world from the non-art world. In so doing, perhaps we can create a situation of trust and generosity between myself and you. Perhaps I can help you with a household chore to share in your daily responsibilities. Perhaps, in exchange, we could discuss my concerns about the art-life dynamic and you could help me to make a sculpture.

contents.title: Nick O‚ÄôBrien on slowing down and nurturing your friendships
contents.generated_title: Nick O‚ÄôBrien on slowing down and nurturing your friendships
contents.content_html:
As you‚Äôve carved out a space for yourself in your work, can you remember having any ‚Äúa-ha‚Äù moments?

I think an ‚Äúa-ha‚Äù moment for me was learning that I could work at a different speed than that of my medium. Digital art, new media, online publishing, and anything to do with computers has this very quick and demanding output regimen, and learning to work outside of those demands has been very helpful. Being able to be slower, being able to be more methodical‚Äîreally just being able to work on projects that take a couple of years.

A key part of this has been learning how to do iterative releasing, as a way of participating in those demands. So, when a whole project isn‚Äôt finished or released yet, I can give people indications of my progress on that project as a way of still participating in those cycles. That‚Äôs been a real positive for me, to just be like, ‚ÄúYou know what? It‚Äôs okay to take my time. It‚Äôs okay for me to dwell in the space of my work.‚Äù

‚Äî Nicholas O'Brien on slowing down and nurturing your friendships
contents.description_html: via https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/nicholas-obrien-on-slowing-down-and-nurturing-your-friendships/
contents.content:
**As you‚Äôve carved out a space for yourself in your work, can you remember having any ‚Äúa-ha‚Äù moments?**

I think an ‚Äúa-ha‚Äù moment for me was learning that I could work at a different speed than that of my medium. Digital art, new media, online publishing, and anything to do with computers has this very quick and demanding output regimen, and learning to work outside of those demands has been very helpful. Being able to be slower, being able to be more methodical‚Äîreally just being able to work on projects that take a couple of years.

A key part of this has been learning how to do iterative releasing, as a way of participating in those demands. So, when a whole project isn‚Äôt finished or released yet, I can give people indications of my progress on that project as a way of still participating in those cycles. That‚Äôs been a real positive for me, to just be like, ‚ÄúYou know what? It‚Äôs okay to take my time. It‚Äôs okay for me to dwell in the space of my work.‚Äù

‚Äî [Nicholas O'Brien on slowing down and nurturing your friendships](https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/nicholas-obrien-on-slowing-down-and-nurturing-your-friendships/)

contents.title: A Social Network for One
contents.description_html: Collectable.art by Bunny Rogers and Nozlee Samadzadeh is part of First Look: Real Artists Ship, a selection of works from recent editions of Seven on Seven. It wasn't long into my collaboration with Bunny Rogers for Rhizome's Seven on Seven conference in 2017 when we realized our similarities might outnumber our perceived differences.

contents.title: 1. Attention - Modern Psyche Podcast
contents.description_html:
Everything around and inside of us is competing for our attention. From ads on bus stops to emotions within. Attention being a single most precious commodity between humans, can create or dismiss worlds into non-existence. So how do we stop giving it away so freely and reclaim back our focus?

http://modernpsyche.libsyn.com/1-attention

https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/1-attention/id1398424185?i=1000415773711&mt=2

contents.title: Madlib on social media
contents.content_html:
Madlib, is it weird not having a mobile phone? Do you ever feel disconnected from the modern world, a place where rappers are constantly tweeting?

Madlib: Social media doesn‚Äôt appeal to me, at all. I ain‚Äôt into posting beats or showing off, none of that bullshit. I‚Äôm all about keeping it a mystery, basically. For me, it‚Äôs all about the music. I haven‚Äôt slept in two days, I‚Äôve just been working. Making music is like therapy. I hope I take my last breath while making a beat. Yes sir, I‚Äôll probably make a hit and then die! I cut off all my friends, threw my phone away, and that‚Äôs because I live strictly for the music.
contents.content:
Madlib, is it weird not having a mobile phone? Do you ever feel disconnected from the modern world, a place where rappers are constantly tweeting?

Madlib: Social media doesn‚Äôt appeal to me, at all. I ain‚Äôt into posting beats or showing off, none of that bullshit. I‚Äôm all about keeping it a mystery, basically. For me, it‚Äôs all about the music. I haven‚Äôt slept in two days, I‚Äôve just been working. Making music is like therapy. I hope I take my last breath while making a beat. Yes sir, I‚Äôll probably make a hit and then die! I cut off all my friends, threw my phone away, and that‚Äôs because I live strictly for the music.

source.title: Madlib and Freddie Gibbs on making one of 2019‚Äôs best rap albums | Dazed
